text: there's been a sharp rise in the death
toll from the devastating earthquake
that hit haiti on saturday almost 1300
people are now known to have died many
more appear to be trapped under the
rubble of collapsed buildings the
epicenter of the 7.2 magnitude quake was
150 kilometers southwest of the capital
port-au-prince
hospitals in the area are inundated and
they are struggling to cope with the
number of injured which has almost
doubled to around 6 000 people
medical teams are being sent from cuba
and ecuador amid concerns about the
approach of a tropical storm james
clayton reports
it's been a devastating 48 hours for
this already impoverished region in the
southwest of the country the earthquake
hit in the morning when many were just
waking up and it's hit hard
it rocks churches hotels and people's
homes they're shaking earth too much for
structures that collapse in on
themselves sometimes on top of people
houses that were supposed to be places
of safety transformed into death traps
we've seen many patients that were uh
trump that were trauma patients we're
talking about orthopedic patients and
surgical trauma patients that's for one
so they had to be addressed uh
emergently urgently some of them had to
be transferred and moved from
their locality to more specialized
facilities or in port-au-prince or
elsewhere
the earthquake was bigger than the one
that hit haiti's capital 11 years ago
which killed up to 300 000 people this
earthquake won't compete with that death
toll but there are fears of thousands of
deaths
there are several factors that make the
aid mission here difficult for one
there's a tropical storm just blowing in
now you might be able to see from the
clouds behind me but there's also
political turmoil here the president was
assassinated only last month and many
people here believe that the haitian
government simply doesn't have the
capacity to deal with a disaster like
this
the route to the affected areas from
haiti's capital is a dangerous road
controlled by gangs many haitians too
are skeptical of international help
after much of the money promised to
rebuild the country after 2010 was
squandered
with the state of emergency called the
people of haiti are now waiting watching
to see what their government and the
international community can do to help
james clayton bbc news porter prince
